title: Nokia 3310 Hands On: Welcome Back To 2000!
description: The 2017 re-issue of the Nokia 3310 is so many things. Its a blockbuster public relations grand slam; its a shameless appeal to the nostalgia of a connected generation; its the cornerstone of an old names fresh beginning. Under it all, of course, the new Nokia 3310 is just a simple little dumbphone  but to me (and probably you), its also irresistible. Im Michael Fisher, aka MrMobile, and this is the Nokia 3310. Again.   [SUBSCRIBE]     [SPONSOR]  MrMobile's MWC coverage is brought to you by Thrifter: a new way to save money from the people behind Mobile Nations. Use Thrifter to shop for everything from gadgets to home goods based on value  not hype. Sign up for the daily mailer at  to get thoughtfully selected tech deals daily from your favorite retailers like Amazon and Best Buy ... without the fluff. transcript: - [Michael] This. This is so many things. It's a blockbuster public relations grand slam. It's a shameless appeal to the nostalgia of a connected generation. And it's the cornerstone of an old name's fresh beginning. Under it all, of course, it's just a simple, little dumb phone, but to me, and probably you, it's also irresistible. This is the Nokia 3310, again. (techno music) If you owned a phone around the turn of the century, you might already know the 3310. It's the pebble shaped cell phone that lasted forever on a charge, and seemed indestructible. If you haven't heard of it, the Saf has a great throwback review over at SuperSaf TV, which you should totally check out. Anyway, at some point between its launch and its 126 millionth sale, the 3310 became an icon of reliability in communications. Flash forward to today. I'm at a party in Barcelona hosted by the current custodian of the Nokia brand. Heritage hangs from the walls. Phone talk is echoing through the halls and anchoring the room beyond the various modern smartphones bearing the Nokia label is the new 3310. I don't even have my camera with me, but I get so excited, I decide to shoot the thing with a smartphone. This is no prototype or demonstration one off. It's a real mobile phone being offered to real people, really soon. And if my fawning hasn't already given it away, I adore it. It's tiny, just like the old one, but modernized just enough to make it clear that this is a 2017 homage, not a dusty antique. The display has been enlarged and promoted to color from black and white. There's now a camera, albeit a very basic one, and the phone is about 40 percent lighter. Put it beside one of today's moderately sized smartphones and it's striking just how much our priorities have changed since 2000, when portability and battery life were everything. Speaking of, Nokia promises 22 hours of talk time and over a month of standby on the new device. It's amazing what kind of endurance you can squeeze out of your phone when the most complex game you can play is Snake. The 3310 is just like a lot of dumb phones in that the keypad is cramped and tough to use, which also makes texting kind of nightmare, until you get re-used to the old predictive text. That kind of ties in with the whole theme here. Yeah, there's a browser, and a media player, and micro SD, and an FM radio, and a handful of other features, but the most complicated thing you're really expected to do with this phone is send the occasional text. That means it's not likely to become anyone's primary device, nor is it likely to sell in huge numbers as some kind of backup phone. More than anything else, this is a throwback built for lovers of retro culture, debuting under one of the most beloved brands in mobile. Some people scratch their glory days itch by buying a $550 Blackberry. Others get a $150 Star Trek Communicator. And now, still others can buy a tribute to one of the building blocks of modern mobility for about 50 bucks. The Nokia 3310 goes on sale in the second quarter. It'll be available in four colors for 49 euro. I'll drop a link in the description where you can sign up on the same email list I'm on, so you'll be one of the first to know when it goes on sale. Drop a comment below with your fond memories of feature phones or flip phones passed, and stay tuned for much more from MWC 2017 as Mr Mobile's week in Barcelona rolls on. That coverage is brought to you by Thrifter, a new way to save money on everything from gadgets to home goods by shopping based on value, and not hype. Sign up at Thrifter.com and get thoughtfully selected tech deals from places like Amazon and Best Buy daily, without all the fluff. 'Til next time, thanks for watching, and stay mobile, my friends.
